title.narrative: Economic Development for Georgia’s Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) through Greenhouses

description.narrative: Over three years, Heifer Georgia, in cooperation with the United Nations High Commission on Refugees (UNHCR) and World Vision Georgia (WVG), will assist 1,440 families directly impacted by the 2008 conflict with Russia. The conflict resulted in 131,169 new Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), most of whom depend upon state allowances and international humanitarian assistance. About 30,000 IDPs are unable to return to their homes and are living in temporary shelters. Some have small garden-sized plots and limited access to social services. The IDPs have inadequate or no access to resources from financial institutions and most are unable to generate their own income from small businesses. Approximately 90 percent of the people live under the poverty line and more than 90 percent are dependent on external food aid. The Georgian government and donor community consider livelihood development and the integration of IDPs into local communities as one of country’s main priorities. To this end, the Economic Development for Georgia’s Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) through Greenhouses project will implement off-season vegetable farming in three different IDP communities along the Administrative Boundary Line (ABL) separating South Ossetia from Georgia. Having worked with the population of concern from the first days following the war, Heifer Georgia identified agriculture as the best potential for livelihood development for both IDPs and local residents in the ABL area. Each greenhouse will grow tomato and cucumber seedlings. During the first year of the project, 480 families will receive seedlings and training. There will be two pass-on cycles. Heifer Georgia will provide three sets of hand-operated working tractors with ploughs and cultivators to assist beneficiary families in land cultivation. Tomatoes will be produced during the off-season period when the prices are high and there are greater demands for them. Additionally, this project will also create 12 full-time jobs, four each in the three communities, to work in the greenhouses.
